Award.AwardTitle: Theoretical Investigations in Classical and Quantum Gravity
Award.AbstractNarration:
Recent observations have shown that about 70% of the energy density in the universe cannot be attributed to matter. The simplest explanation of this `dark energy' comes from the cosmological constant that Einstein had initially introduced in his fundamental equations of general relativity. However, for most of the 20th century, it was widely believed that the cosmological constant is zero because all observations were compatible with this simplest possibility. Therefore, the detailed mathematical theories describing the dynamics of compact astronomical objects such as colliding black holes and neutron stars, and gravitational waves they source, was based on this assumption. The goal of the first part of this project is to systematically extend that theory to include a non-zero cosmological constant. The extension will provide a firmer foundation for gravitational wave science. The second part of the project contains studies at the interface of strong gravity and quantum physics. They address fundamental issues related to the quantum evaporation of black holes and the physics of the earliest epoch of our universe when gravity is strong and quantum physics indispensable. The proposed research will have an impact on a broad range of research areas, including general relativity, geometric analysis, cosmology, quantum field theory, and computational science. As a result, through this research, young scientists will be trained in inter-disciplinary science. Currently, these researchers include members of under-represented groups. Through his editorship of series commemorating the centennial of the discovery of general relativity, the PI will commission monographs aimed at communicating the latest advances in science and technology to young researchers. Finally, as in the past, personnel supported by this grant will contribute vigorously to outreach activities through videos, semi-popular articles and public lectures.

The first part of the project will address issues arising from the fact that even a tiniest value if the cosmological constant can cast a long shadow on the theory of gravitational waves. As of now, we do not even have a gauge invariant notion of gravitational waves in full, non-linear general relativity with a positive cosmological constant. The goal is to construct a rigorous framework to fill this gap and use it to extract the physics of gravitational waves in a more reliable fashion. The results will open new avenues for analytic and numerical work in the study of the gravitational collapse, compact binary coalescence, energy, momentum and angular momentum emission in such processes, post-Newtonian and post-Minkowskian approximation methods, etc. They are also likely to stimulate research in geometric analysis through new mathematical conjectures (related to positivity of a new notion of energy). The second part of the project will address two types of issues: i) the conceptually fundamental question of whether information is lost in evaporation of black holes; and, ii) the emerging interplay between loop quantum gravity and observations related to the very early universe. This is possible because loop quantum cosmology is now sufficiently mature to make predictions for future observations based on its pre-inflationary dynamics, and to use current observations to seek fundamental principles that presumably dictate the initial conditions for our universe.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF proposal supported a number of research, education and training, and outreach activities.  Research supported by this grant led to 2 advanced monographs, 44 journal articles and 3 book chapters. Two (female) students completed their Ph.D. and six post-doctoral fellows, supported in part by this grant, were trained in classical and quantum gravitational physics, cosmology and computational physics. Researchers supported by this grant also undertook a large number of outreach activities (see, for example, http://igc.psu.edu/outreach/index.shtml ) especially during the centennial celebrations of Einstein's discovery of general relativity. A 43 minute YouTube video describing research supported by this ongoing grant has received over 300,000 views (https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IFcQuEw0oY8&feature=c4-overview&list=UUtOgKmAM4MeFu-jd-HB3_cg )

Two highlights of our research findings are summarized below.

1. Recent observations have shown that about 70% of the energy density in the universe cannot be attributed to matter. The simplest explanation of this `dark energy' comes from the cosmological constant that Einstein had initially introduced in his fundamental equations of general relativity. However, for most of the 20th century, it was widely believed that the cosmological constant is zero because all observations were compatible with this simplest possibility. Therefore, the detailed mathematical theories describing the dynamics of compact astronomical objects such as colliding black holes and neutron
stars, and gravitational waves they source, was based on this assumption. Through a series of 4 papers, PI and his students initiated a systematic program to extend the existing framework to incorporate the presence of dark energy. In particular, they successfully addressed a 100 year old challenge to generalize Einstein's celebrated 1916 formula describing the power radiated by a time changing `mass quadrupole' through gravitational waves by accommodating dark energy.

2. A second major thrust of the research program was to explore the very early universe. Through a series of three papers the PI and his team created a two way bridge between observations made by the (WMAP and) PLANCK satellite missions and Loop Quantum Gravity (LQG), a candidate theory aimed at unifying general relativity with quantum physics. In particular, according to loop quantum gravity, just as matter has elementary constituents, so does space-time geometry. Einstein's continuum is an approximation that works well under normal circumstances but breaks down near the big-bang and inside black holes where Einstein's space-time simply ends.  In these circumstances we have to take the `atomic structure' underlying the space-time continuum seriously. LQG provides a concrete avenue to do so by providing equations that govern these `atoms' themselves. They predict that space-time does not end nor does the physics come to a halt at the big-bang; big bang is replaced by a big bounce. The `quantum space-time' of LQG is much larger than what general relativity had us believe. Over the last 5 years, PI's group carried out a systematic investigation of the possible observational signatures of this prediction. Their detailed calculations showed that certain features seen in the primordial radiation --called the cosmic microwave background (CMB)--that are surprising from the standpoint of the standard (inflationary) paradigm can be naturally accounted for in the LQG paradigm. Each of these effects is small, at the edge of being statistically significant. However, the PLANCK team, who reported them, has emphasized that if any of the anomalies have a primordial origin, then their large-scale nature would suggest an explanation rooted in fundamental physics. The LQG mechanism falls squarely in this category. Finally, the CMB observations reported by the PLANCK team can also be regarded to test details of the atomic structure of geometry predicted by LQG. Just as energy of atoms is quantized ?i.e., assumes specific discrete values?observables associated with geometry are also quantized. The most basic of these predictions is that areas of surfaces have a specific minimum (non-zero) value. This value was arrived at without reference to cosmology. Therefore it is significant that best-fit value compatible with the PLANCK team observations turned out to agree with the LQG value within observational errors.

In addition, projects supported by this NSF grant led to several independent results in cosmology, theory of gravitational waves, math4matical theory of black holes and computational physics. Impact of the results is illustrated by the fact the researchers supported by this grant were invited to give some 35-40 talks at national and internal conferences and workshops, and seminars at leading research institutions worldwide. In addition, the British journal Reports on Progress in Physics commissioned an article by the PI to summarize the findings on implications of a positive cosmological constant on general relativity.  Several results were highlighted in science outreach media such as the German magazine Bild der Wissenschaft  and British online service CQG+  that serves as the outreach companion of the Institute of Physics Journal Classical and Quantum gravity.
